titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. We received formal visits of Ceremony from the Count de Lens, Mayor of the City, and five of his Adjoints, from the President of the tribunal of Commerce, Mr Van Aken, and several of its members— From Mr Van Huffelt President of the Society of Fine Arts, and several of its members, among whom was the Painter Paelinck; and from many of the respectable Inhabitants of the City— We paid visits in person to the Intendant Count D’hane de Steenhuyse, the Mayor, whom we did not find at home, and to the British Plenipotentiaries— There was a single Servant there, who informed us the family were all at prayers— We alighted, but after waiting a few minutes in the room below, came away and left Cards— The Intendant received us in a full Court dress— We also called at Mr Meulemeester’s, but they were not at home— To the rest of our acquaintance we sent Cards— We all dined at Mr Van Caneghem’s—the Invitation was for three O’Clock but her daughter Madame De Naeyer mistook the hour, and it was between five and six when we sat down— The party was of about 25 persons—the Meulemeester’s, Van Aken’s, and our Company— I came home to my lodgings, after having been to the Theatre, where I saw Francoise de Foix, and Monsieur Pistache ou le jour de l’an— It was a day of so much bustle and confusion, that the greatest part of it was dissipated.

2. V:30. The pressure upon my time is excessive, and accidents continually occurring prevent me from retrieving it— I wrote this morning an Answer to the requisition signed by Messrs: Bayard, Clay and Russell, and presented to me on Saturday by Mr Clay— I gave it to Mr Bayard at his chamber— This subject so insignificant in itself gives me more trouble, than if it was important it possibly could— It is one of those occasions upon which with an extreme anxiety to act with propriety, I feel the hazard of committing an error— The manner in which the paper was drawn up, signed, and presented to me, was, I think, irregular; the paper is totally different from that which Mr Clay promised to draw up, and is drawn in a manner not a little embarrassing to me— It neither specifies the papers to be delivered nor the persons, to whom I am to deliver them. I mentioned these Circumstances in my answer to the Letter, and added that I had objections to the request itself which I should state at the meeting of the Mission— Before delivering to Mr Bayard my answer, I called at Mr Gallatin’s chamber, and shewed him the requisition to me— He said he had seen it before— That Mr Clay had shewn it to him and asked him to sign it. He had answered that he would sign it, with the addition that he was of a different opinion; upon which Mr Clay had preferred that he should not sign it at-all— I had many new years visits again this morning; some in person, and other’s by Cards— Among the rest was Mr Goulburn, who brought me the Times to the 30th.— He informed me that Lord Gambier and Dr: Adams had left the City this Morning— We all dined with the Hanoverian Lieutenant General Baron Charles Alten, excepting Mr Clay who was unwell and sent an excuse. The Intendant and Mayor were there, and ten or fifteen English, Hanoverian and Belgian Officers— General Lyon was one of them— About eight we went to the Concert and Redoute Extraordinary on occasion of the Peace— The Hall was crowded as full as it could hold— The Concert was just over when we went in, but they played Hail Columbia, the second time to greet us— There was an Inscription at one end of the Hall— Harmonie, entre Albion et Columbia. La Paix, Conclue XXIV. Decembre— I maid a short stay there, and withdrew about nine, when the dancing began— I went an passed an hour with Mr and Mrs Smith— Mr Van Huffelt requested Mr Gallatin and myself to give him each an hour on Wednesday, which we promised.

3. VI: I wrote to my wife; which employed me all the morning;—and I am devoting all my leisure moments to the copying of the Treaty; in hourly expectation of the arrival of Captain Jones from Dunkirk to take the third Copy.— I had a morning visit from Mr De Naeyer— We all dined at the Intendant’s— It was a dinner given on the occasion. We were invited at half-past four, but did not sit down to table until near six; nor rise from it before nine— Mr Goulburn was there— As were Generals Alten and Lyon, Major and Mrs Heise, and Miss Halkett— The St: Cecilia Band of Music attended and performed the National airs, God save the king, and Hail Columbia— The Intendant toasted the allied powers, the deliverers of this Country and of Europe. His Britannic Majesty, the United States of America, the Sovereign Prince of the Netherlands, and the Congress at Ghent, and its happy conclusion— I gave for a toast le Bonheur de la Belgique; and Mr Goulburn gave the prosperity of the City of Ghent. While we were at table one of the Officers was called out to quell a riot among some of the Hanoverian soldiers in which a man had been murdered— I came home very shortly after dinner.

4. VI: I finished this morning the copy of the Treaty. I had requested a meeting of the Mission at one O’Clock, but it failed. I paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Goulburn, and took to him the Newspapers that he had lent us, and the Affidavit concerning the sale of Negroes taken from the Southern States which had been promised him by Mr Clay— I found them much engaged in packing up and making preparations for their departure— Mr Goulburn consented to stay only from complaisance to attend the public entertainment to be given to-morrow in honour of the Peace; and is to leave the City on Saturday— We all dined and spent the Evening at Mr Meulemeester’s, with his usual family party— While we were at table his daughter, Marrianne, a pretty child about twelve years old came in and played upon the Harp, and sung several couplets complimentary to us, written by Mr Cornelissen— Her Cousin, Madame Gréban’s daughter Esther, who is about a year older played Hail Columbia! Copies of the verses were given to each of us, and Mr Gallatin asked for a copy of the tune, which was promised— I played in the Evening at Boston with Mrs Van Aken, and Mrs Charles Van Aken— The party broke up between eleven and twelve at Night.

5. VI:30. On rising this Morning, instead of diplomatic papers, and Letters concerning the loan, of which I have a large file to copy; instead of the arrears with my Correspondents which I have to bring up, and the still more urgent arrears of this journal which are increasing every day, the fancy struck me of answering the Couplets yesterday sung by Mr Meulemeester’s daughter— So, farewell for this day all grave and reverend occupation— I could think of nothing but my Couplets— After preparing them, four Stanzas in number, I went out to a Bookseller’s shop—purchased three small volumes of Étrennes Géographiques, with coloured plates, packed them up, with my Song, addressed them to Miss Meulemeester, and then wrote a Note to her mother, requesting her to present them in my name to her daughter— The morning was now gone— A meeting of the Mission at Mr: Gallatin’s chamber had been appointed for one O’Clock; but he was gone out— It failed again for the second time— Another important question arose; how we were to dress for the banquet of this day— To settle it, Mr Smith at my request called upon Mr Goulburn, and enquired how he proposed to go— He answered, in Uniform, and we accordingly all went in Uniform— The banquet was at the Hotel de Ville; and was given by subscription by the principal Gentlemen of the City— We sat down to table about five O’Clock, in the largest Hall of the building fitted up for the occasion with white Cotton hangings the American and British flags were intertwined together under olive trees, at the head of the Hall. Mr Goulburn and myself were seated between the Intendant and the Mayor, at the Centre of the Cross-Piece of the Table— There were about ninety persons seated at the table. As we went into the Hall, Hail Columbia was performed by the Band of Music— It was followed by God Save the King; and these two airs were alternately repeated during the dinner time, until Mr Goulburn thought they became tiresome— I was of the same opinion— The Intendant and the Mayor alternately toasted His Britannic Majesty and the United States; the allied powers, and the Sovereign Prince— The Negotiators and the Peace— I then remarked to Mr Goulburn that he must give the next toast, which he did— It was the Intendant and the Mayor; the City of Ghent; its prosperity; and our gratitude for their hospitality and the many acts of kindness that we had received from them— I gave the next and last toast, which was Ghent, the City of Peace— May the gates of the Temple of Janus here closed, not be opened again for a century. There were some french Couplets, written by a Baron d’Exaerde, which were distributed, and should have been sung— But they were omitted, and were not worth singing— We rose from table soon after seven, and went into the Hall where the Ball had commenced. The Company was numerous, and the dancing animated— I met there Madame Meulemeester, who told me she had received my Note, and had given my present to her daughter— I came home about ten in the Evening.

6. VI. At length the feasting is finished, and I can return with less interruption to serious occupations. I wrote again to my wife which employed the morning. We had at length the meeting of the Mission, in Mr Gallatin’s chamber at two O’Clock. It was much hurried, Mr Bayard and Mr Clay being in the midst of the preparations for their departure to-morrow Morning— I mentioned the letters I had received from Mr Bourne asking if we could furnish the Passport for the Herald, if they should find it expedient to dispatch her before the cessation of hostilities; Mr Clay was for refusing it altogether; thinking it was a mere private speculation of individual profit to be derived from the possession of the Passport— Mr Bayard and Mr Gallatin were for letting them have the Passport; but only upon Condition that the vessel should take any dispatches there might be to send, and without any expence to the Public.— As Captain Reuben Jones has not made his appearance, in consequence
of the letter written to him by Mr Bayard, it is concluded that he had left Dunkirk before it arrived there, and that he will not come— Mr Bayard being very anxious to have the third Copy of the Treaty dispatched, proposed that it should be sent by Mr Goulburn, who goes to-morrow Morning, to Mr Beasley, with a request to him to forward it by the first possible opportunity, and with authority to him to employ a special messenger for the purpose. This was agreed to; with the Understanding that if Captain Jones should yet come, and be willing to proceed to London, and take the Treaty upon the terms offered him by Mr Bayard’s letter, that is for £120 Sterling, he shall have that privilege. I asked Mr Bayard if he had a copy of his Letter to Jones, but he had none— A letter to the mission was received last Saturday from Emile Soubiran, an impostor, who passed himself off in America for a Count Crillon, and who was concerned in the affair of Captain Henry. This fellow now sends us extracts from several Letters of Mr Monroe, Mr Serrurier the French Minister, and Mr Brent a Senator from Virginia— He pretends that sixteen thousand dollars were promised him for having prevailed upon Henry to give up his papers, and he now says that unless we cause that sum to be paid to him within a Month he will go to America and publish all those Letters. It was now questioned what was to be done with this man’s Letter, and it was resolved to leave it unanswered. It was also proposed to send his Letter to the Government, but no resolution to that effect was adopted. I now mentioned the Letter I had received from three members of the Mission, Messrs: Bayard, Clay and Russell and the answer I had given to it. I stated that I had not understood that any Resolution had passed at the meeting of 30th December, and that the paper sent to me was totally different from that which Mr Clay had promised to draw up, as it neither specified the papers I was to deliver up, nor the person to whom I should deliver them.— That I had expected Mr Clay’s draft would be submitted to the Mission for Consideration, and that I should have had an opportunity of making my objections to it.— Mr Clay said that a Majority of the Mission had expressed their opinions at the meeting, and Mr Bayard said I had refused to put it to vote; and said that I knew very well what the vote would be— I immediately denied having ever said so. I admitted that at the previous meeting I had declined putting it to vote and had said I considered the custody of the Papers as my right, subject to the orders of our Government, and not subject to a vote— But on further reflection I had said at the meeting of the thirtieth of December, that I would deliver up any papers specified to me, to any person named to me by a majority of the Mission, authorised by them to receive them from me, and to give me a receipt from them— That so far from having said I knew very well what the vote would be, I had not known what it would be; I did not know what Mr: Bayards opinion would be, I was not conscious that he had expressed any opinion, and I inclined from the precedent of the former Mission in which he had acquiesced at least, to the belief that his opinion would now have been for the same course. Mr: Bayard now said that his recollection was different of the precedent of the former Mission— That he himself had all those papers; they were in his trunk on board the Neptune— He was sure at least that he had brought the Book with him, and Mr Hughes had now taken it home— Mr Gallatin repeated that as he recollected he had received from Mr: Harris, all the papers until 31. October, when he, Gallatin had withdrawn from the Mission; and he was confident they were in his trunk on board the Neptune— Mr: Clay was now set at his ease with regard to the Precedent; and said he did not believe there was any such usage, as I referred to— That at least there was none such in the British Government— That Lord Gambier had said the Papers were always returned to the public office, and all theirs would be so. Mr Gallatin said Lord Gambier might not know much about it, and Mr Bayard said he considered his authority as nothing, or next to nothing— But that was what he had said— It was evident that Bayard himself was the person who had asked of Lord Gambier the question; but that he felt a little aukward at having been to Lord Gambier to ascertain what it would be proper to do with our papers— Mr Clay then asked if I had come to a final determination concerning the papers; that if I had and determined to keep them it might be proper to transmit to the Secretary of State a copy of the letter from the three members to me, and of my answer. I said certainly, it had always been my expectation and intention that copies of those letters should be transmitted to the Secretary of State— That I had not come to a final determination concerning the papers— I had wished to state at this Meeting of the Mission that the time was premature for a final disposal of them— That with a written demand
from three members of the Mission, to have the papers packed up and sent away, I should be reluctant at keeping them; but unless the papers were specified I knew not which to send away, nor which to reserve; and unless the person were named to me, I knew not to whom to deliver them— I knew not where nor how to send them to the Neptune— The mission was not terminated— We had just communicated to the British Government that we were empowered to conclude a Treaty of Commerce— It was probable they would accept the proposal after the ratification of the Peace. In that case the effects and Papers would be wanted again— I considered myself entitled to the custody of the Papers and if they were to be taken out of my hands the person must be named to whom I should give them and must give me a receipt for them. Mr Clay said there was the principle and the modus— As to any right of mine to keep the papers, he could not reason about it— He could not think or speak of it with Patience— There was nothing in the Nature of our Government, nothing in the nature of the Mission, that gave any colour to it— If it had been asked as a matter of courtesy, he was willing to shew all suitable respect to the first named member of the Mission— But a privilege! a prerogative! he could never acknowledge or submit to it. That as to specifying the papers, that could not have been done by him because they were in my possession. That there was no necessity for naming the person to whom I should deliver them— I might take them on with me to Paris, and give them to any other member of the Mission who would return by the Neptune— Or I might send them by Mr Smith, who would probably go to the Neptune from hence— He was desirous of parting in friendship with every body; we had here transacted our business together, he hoped to the Satisfaction of our Country; and he did not wish to go away with any heart-burnings between any of us. All this was said in an acrimonious and menacing tone— I said it was not improbable, I should return to the United States in the Neptune, myself— I had brought a list of all the books and other effects except the papers, which was on the table— I should pack them up and leave them here to be sent where and how the mission should direct. The copying press and the Papers I intended to take with me to Paris, and would deliver them ultimately to any person named and authorized to receive them, according as I had offered, by a majority of the Mission— The paper I had received was not an act of the majority— It was the act of three members— “And although (said Mr Clay) those three members form a majority”! Certainly said I; an act of the greater number, without consulting the other members, is not an act of the majority— Clay now lost all the remnant of his temper—and broke out with “you dare not, you cannot, you shall not insinuate that there has been a cabal of three members against you; no person shall impute any thing of the kind to me with impunity— It is not unexampled that a paper should be drawn up and signed without consulting the whole mission. You gave me to sign the very day when I took this paper to you, the answer to a Letter from the Prussian Minister at the Hague— It was already signed by two members of the Mission, and I had never seen it— Nay, I did not know there was such a letter to answer— The letter I presented to you was shewn to Mr Gallatin; he was consulted upon it, and might have signed it, if he had pleased— As it was addressed to you, and known to be against your opinion it was not necessary to consult you.” I replied “what I dare say, I have dared to say in writing. Gentlemen may draw from it what inferences they please; I am not answerable for them— I am perfectly satisfied that your letter and my answer should be transmitted to our Government, and I assure you that if you do not transmit them I shall.”— I said nothing in reply to Mr Clay’s example that he had given of a paper, drawn up by one member and signed without further consultation of the Mission— This has been done several times in cases where there was no diversity of opinion, and where every member previously to signing the paper might have stated any objection or proposed any alteration, upon which the Mission would have been immediately consulted— But it has happened in no case where there was any difference of opinion— The case relied upon by Mr Clay was an unfortunate one— The letter from the Prussian Minister was dated 13. December— Two Copies of it had been transmitted to the Secretary of State, with a letter mentioning the substance of its Contents, which letter Mr Clay had signed— The necessity of answering it had been mentioned at several successive Meetings of the Mission, and Mr Gallatin had made the first draft of the answer at the meeting of 29. December, while we were in Session. I had made a second draft on the 30th: and then with Mr Gallatin’s approbation, at Mr Russell’s request, wrote it off the morning that Mr Russell went away, that it might be ready for him to sign— This was the reason why it was definitively prepared without consultation of the whole Mission upon its Contents— But if Mr Clay had objected to any thing in it, certainly it could not have been sent without a decision of the mission upon it— On my reply to the dare not, and cannot and shall not, Mr Clay cooled down, and said that if I had
not come to a final determination, he should wish that our Letters might not be transmitted to the Government.— That if I should go home in the Neptune there need be no further question upon the subject— That it would cast some dishonour upon us all to say any thing to the Government about it— That it would look as if we had fallen to a scramble after a few books and papers— I said that if such was his desire, I was perfectly willing that the Government should not be informed there had been any such question among us—and to say no more about it. Mr Gallatin proposed that the Books and effects except the papers should be sent to Mr Beasley at London, to be kept by him subject to further orders— This was agreed to— And I retain the papers, also until further order— The meeting was then indefinitely adjourned— I took the Despatch N. 10. to the Secretary of State, to Mr Smith to be copied; and was employed all the remainder of the day and Evening in copying other papers and making up the packet to be dispatched with the Treaty.— Mr Smith called on me in the Evening, and took the packet with a letter for Mr Beasley, to Mr Goulburn— Mr Bayard and Mr Clay who are going to-morrow Morning together, came and took leave of me at my chamber.—

7. VI: I resume the copying of papers respecting the loan, the originals of which I consider as being of right in Mr: Gallatin’s hands— He is the person first named in that Commission, and I told him I thought he had a right to keep the papers— He said he cared nothing about them, but determined to take them— Mr Bayard and Mr Clay went about six O’Clock this Morning; in the Diligence, for Lille— They took the whole Carriage for themselves, for the sake of getting all their baggage over the frontiers, into France— At Lille they propose to take a light Carriage for themselves, and still to send on most of their baggage by the Stage. Mr Goulburn also departed with his family this day for London— The two Young Smiths of Philadelphia went to Bruxelles. I answered this day several Letters which I had received from Mr Bourne, and Wrote to Messrs: Willink & Van Staphorst of Amsterdam. The arrears of my Journal are still running up.

8. VI. Mr Gallatin postpones his departure from day to day for the arrangement of his papers— I find still more to do with mine— I continue copying the papers respecting the loan; and this Evening wrote to Mr Crawford, requesting him to send me a Passport. Spent part of the Evening with Mrs Smith; and found with her a Madam Marouques and her daughter— Ladies belonging to Bruges, who are here upon some business and lodge in the neighbourhood of Mrs Smith.

9. VI: This morning I received a letter addressed to the Mission from Mr Hughes, dated new-Year’s day at Bordeaux. He expected to sail the next day in the Transit, for the United States. This Evening I made a copy of this Letter, to send by Mr: Gallatin to Messrs. Bayard, Clay, and Russell.— Mr Cornelissen paid me a visit, together with a Mr Kerchove, called the Baron d’Exaerde, and styling himself a Count of the Holy Roman Empire. I had met him several times at this house last Summer, at the Table d’Hote. He was the author of the Couplets, distributed, and intended to have been sung at the Banquet of last Thursday— He promised to make enquiry of Mr Van Saseghem, when I could go and see his collection of Pictures— And he afterwards sent me a note, informing me that Mr Saseghem would receive me at eleven O’Clock to-morrow Morning. Mr Cornelissen promised to call upon me on Wednesday, and go with me to see the pictures of a Doctor Van Rotterdam— Remainder of the Evening at Mr Smith’s chambers.

10. VI. Finished copying the papers relating to the loan; and returned all the originals to Mr Gallatin— Upon arranging his papers before his departure, he found in his trunk all the papers of the prior Mission which he thought he had sent on board the Neptune; and which Mr Bayard was so confident were in his possession— Mr Gallatin shewed them to me; and said that if it should be finally determined to send the papers of the present Mission to be deposited in the department of State the same thing should be done with these— I went at twelve O’Clock, and saw Mr Van Saseghem’s Collection of Paintings— He has a few good pictures— But nothing comparable to that of Mr Schamp— He has barely one Hall furnished with them— There was one of the pictures the subject of which I did not immediately understand— I asked him what it was— He said C’est le Roi Joseph—ne voyéz vous pas ses freres— As I was returning home I stopp’d at a Bookseller’s shop, purchased the works of Madame & Mademoiselle Deshouliéres, and sent them to Miss Esther Gréban, with a note to her mother requesting her to present them to her in my name. In the shop I heard the shocking Story of two young men of this City, named Amelinck, who were assassinated last Night at Tronchiennes by four Hanoverian Soldiers— I went in the Evening to the Theatre, and saw La Soirée Orageuse, Musick by d’Alayrac, and Alexis ou l’erreur d’un bon Père. Mrs Greban told me she had received the books and given them to her daughter.

11. V:45. Mr Gallatin is still so much engaged in his preparations for departure that he did not get away this day. At his request I endorsed his Passport which is from Mr Crawford and the Prince de Bénévent. We have hitherto dined together, and by ourselves between four and five O’Clock— This day I dined at the table d’hote, at half past one— Just before the dinner was announced Mr Cornelissen called upon me, to go with me to see the Pictures of Doctor Van Rotterdam. Mr Cornelissen dined with us at the Table d’Hôte. We went to see the pictures immediately after dinner— But it was already nearly dark— The Doctor has some good pictures of the Flemish School— Jan Steen, Wouvermans, Teniers, Van der Werf, and Mieris. None of them very remarkable, and his house is in one of the darkest alleys of the City. Two thirds of his pictures too are heaped one over another upon the floor, as his house is so small he has no room for them— We remained there until it became quite dark, and the Doctor was called away to a patient— Mr Cornelissen returned with me to my chamber where we sat discussing literature, and the fine Arts until 6 O’Clock— I then went to the theatre and saw Orphée et Euridice, Music of Glück, and le Nouveau Seigneur de Village, by Boieldieu; composed, Mr Meulemeester says at St: Petersburg. After the play, I went and passed an hour at Mr Smith’s.

12. VI: Soon after rising this Morning, I found that Mr Gallatin’s Post-horses were at his Carriage in the yard— I went into his chamber and took leave of him— He went off at eight O’Clock and goes directly to Geneva— I found Mr Meulemeester with him in his chamber—he had called also to take leave. I received two letters from my wife, one of them enclosing a letter from my Mother, dated 29. August, and one for Mr Smith from his father— I had also received yesterday two Letters from Mr: Harris, which I answered this Evening— Dined at the Table d’hote where there were only four other persons, and passed the latter part of the Evening at Mrs Smith’s, where I met Madame Marouques and her Daughter— Mr Smith was at the Ball.

13. VI: Mr Lieven Bauwens, a manufacturer, and inventor of machinery for manufactures had invited me to go with him, and Mr Cornelissen to Tronchiennes a Village about three miles distant from the City, where he resides, to see some of his inventions. They came at Noon— I enquired at what time we should return; Mr Cornelissen told me about four O’Clock. I sent word to Mr and Mrs Smith that I would come and dine with them at that hour— We rode about a mile out of the City, and walked the remainder of the way, crossing two Canals in boats. At Tronchiennes, Mr Bauwens introduced us to his wife, a handsome and agreeable woman— She had with her a daughter, about five years old— We were served with a Collation, which brought us to three O’Clock—then an hour to see the machinery—wheels for spinning flax, very ingenious but which have not been profitable to their inventor. Almost all the manufactures of the Country have been ruined since they have been laid open to the competition of the English— Mr Bauwens shewed us three medals of honour which he has received from the City, and from the French Government, for his improvements— He is now desirous of going with his family to America; for the sake he says, of having a Country. He has had several conversations with Mr Clay, concerning his project, and enquired of me this day whether I thought he should find encouragement for his establishments in America— I told him I had no doubt he would; particularly with the aid of his labour-saving machines. He says he has another machine in the City which he will shew me; the secret of which he has not yet disclosed— A very few of his spinning wheels are at work at Tronchiennes— His Manufacture in the City is at the Chartreux; part of the buildings where the British Plenipotentiaries resided— It was near five O’Clock when we left Tronchiennes. We saw the grave of the young man who was murdered last week by the Hanoverian Soldiers— His brother lies at the point of Death, and cannot recover.— The people in the neighborhood are excessively exasperated against these troops— A boat with six of them, armed came and landed on the grounds of Mr Bauwens before his door, while we were there— He sallied out immediately and ordered them away— They went off quietly; but the child was frightened and began to cry— We returned as we had gone out, and it was six O’Clock when we came into the City— I stopped at Mr Smith’s, and found them at dinner— They had waited for me nearly two hours— After dining with them I returned to my chamber at the Hotel; closed and sent off my letters and was employed all the remainder of the Evening in writing.

14. V:45. Engaged again the whole day in writing; copying the remaining papers connected with the Treaty, and beginning to retrieve the arrears of this Journal— They have been increasing until they can be no longer neglected; from the day preceding the signature of the Treaty. It is but now that I have brought them up to the close of the last year, and this day I began upon that now current— Dined at the table d’hôte at half past one— Walked round the Coupure after dinner, and wrote again in the Evening. The latter part of it I passed at Mrs Smith’s— She had been upon a visit to her neighbours, Madame Marouques and her daughter.

15. V:45. Employed the whole morning in writing to retrieve the arrears of this Journal. At one O’Clock Mr Charles Meulemeester called upon me, and I went with him and dined at his brother’s— The only other company besides the family were Mr and Madame Gréban, and Mr: Cornelissen— In the Evening we went to the Theatre and saw Camille, ou le Souterrein— Le Nouveau Seigneur de Village and Reveries renouvellées des Grecs, a parody of Iphigenie in Tauride— The play began at 5. and finished not long before eleven.

16. VI— After dining at half-past one at the table d’hote, I took a long walk round from the Antwerp Gate on the Ramparts and the Coupure— Then returned to my chamber and wrote again until eight in the Evening— I then called at Mrs Smith’s. They were both gone to pass the Evening at Mrs: Meulemeester’s— I went into the reading room of the Literary Society, and looked over the French Newspapers— Then returned home— After I was in bed Mr Smith knocked at my chamber door, with a letter from Mr Hughes; but finding my door locked took it home with him— I am still labouring upon arrears.

17. VI. Continued writing; yet in arrear— Wrote to my wife, and sent a copy of Mr Hughes’s last Letter, to My Colleagues at Paris— Mr Cornelissen called upon me, with a Letter from Mr Van Huffel to Mr Clay; containing copies of the likenesses of Messrs: Clay and Gallatin that he had taken— Mr Van Huffel again requested that I would call upon him to sit, and I sent him word I would call at eleven O’Clock to-morrow Morning.— I begin to be anxious to get away from this place, for I feel that am now wasting time here upon trifles— I spent the Evening from 8 until 10 O’Clock at Mr Smith’s— The Canals in this City are for the first time this Season, frozen over.

18. VI:30. Having gone through the copying of the Correspondence with the British Plenipotentiaries I am now employed with other papers connected with the business of the mission— I had engaged to call at eleven O’Clock this morning upon Mr Van Huffel the painter— He had taken likenesses in pencil of Mr Gallatin, Mr Bayard & Mr Clay; and had asked me to give him an hour for the same purpose— While there, he urged me to let him take my Picture in Oil-Colours and on Canvass to which I finally consented— I sat an hour and a half—then returned to the Hotel to dinner— Wrote after dinner in my chamber, until six and then went to the Theatre, and saw Le Comte d’Albert an Opera—the Music is of Gretry, and not in his best manner— And Le Chien de Montargis ou La Foret de Bondi, a Melo-drama, the singularity of which is that a dog is one of the principal performers— It has had great success in Paris and London; and was performed here this Evening for the first time— The house was very thin; but the dog performed his part very well— The ground is at last covered with Snow, and this day I have seen two or three Sledges in the Streets.

19. VI:15. The weather having become very cold I find a reluctance at rising so early as I ought.— I copied this morning the papers from Soubiran, and this Evening a paper from Mr Lloyd to R. Smith Secretary of State in 1809. concerning the Northern Boundary of the United States— At eleven this morning I went to Mr Van Huffel’s and sat to him until half past one— Mr Cornelissen dined with us at the Hotel, and invited me to go with him and dine with one of his friends to-morrow— I walked round the Coupure— Returned and wrote at my Chamber until 8 O’Clock—then went to Mr Smith and passed the Evening until eleven at Cards with them, and Madame and Miss Marouques.

20 VI:15. Having nearly finished the copying of Papers which I had proposed, I began this day to make out a list of the papers belonging to the joint Mission, and also the arranging of them in order to be sent away if it should be finally so determined— I received this Morning a Note from Mr Cornelissen, apologizing for not having the dinner, being obliged to go out of town to meet his brother— I wrote to my wife, and at Noon called on Mr Van Huffel to sit for my Picture. He invited me to go with him in the Evening to see the Students of the Academy, at their Studies— He called upon me, between five and six this afternoon and I went with him— There are nearly four hundred Students divided into four Classes, besides a separate Class for Architecture— The first is of Children just beginning, who draw from engravings— The second Class draw also from Prints, and almost all from the same design; they draw for places— The third Class draw from Statues, which they call à la bosse; and the fourth from living naked model— They pursue these studies every
evening from 5 to 7 O’Clock, during the Winter Months from October to March. The expence is supported chiefly by subscription— I called for half an hour at Mr Smith’s, and found Mrs Smith quite unwell— The weather is cold, the ground covered with Snow, and many sledges about the City.

21. VI: I still copy a few papers, and shall be obliged to leave many which I intended to have copied, but for which I shall not have time— At noon I called upon Mr Van Huffel and sat until half past one— I asked him his price for the picture, but he prefers leaving it to my generosity— The painting is a good likeness, but indifferent as a work of art— Mrs Smith sent me word that she was still confined to her bed, and that the Ladies I was to meet there this Evening would not come— From three in the afternoon, immediately after dinner, until ten in the Evening I was busied arranging papers; and continuing to make the list of those belonging to the joint Mission.

22. VI: From the hour of rising until that of dinner I was engaged in arranging my accounts and preparing and arranging my papers— Mr Cornelissen called upon me— He has seen my picture at Mr Van Huffel’s, and thinks it a likeness pour le materiel. After dinner I walked round the Ramparts and the Coupure from the Antwerp Gate.— Returned to the assortment of Papers, until eight in the Evening, and then went and spent two hours with Mr: and Mrs Smith.

23. VII. By day light—the first time since the month of November— Mr Bauwens called upon me this morning to shew me some samples of his thread and linen. I had but half an hour to give this day to Mr Van Huffel. Mr Cornelissen dined with us at the Table d’Hote. After dinner Mr Bauwens called again, and I went with him and Mr Cornelissen to see the machine of his invention for spinning. Afterwards I went to the Card manufactory of his brother in Law; which is far inferior to the Card-manufactories that I have seen in Boston. On returning home I continued my preparations for packing up, until 8 O’Clock, and then spent the remainder of the Evening at Mr Smith’s Apartments— We played at Boston with Madame and Mademoiselle Marouques until near Midnight— Mrs Smith and her child were both unwell.

24. VI:45. Again by daylight, and I perceive in myself a strong propensity to relax in my practice of early rising.— I had engaged to dine with Mr and Mrs Smith; but Mr Cornelissen came, and persuaded me to go and dine with his friend Mr: Van Toers, a lawyer— I sent an excuse to Mr Smith, and Mr Cornelissen called for me at Mr Van Huffel’s at One O’Clock— We dined at this Mr Van Toers’s, only with his family and Mr Solvyns, the Editor of the celebrated work upon the Hindoos— After dinner I went home, finished my letter to my wife, and proceeded in the preparations for my departure, until 8 in the Evening; and then called for a couple of hours at Mr Smith’s chambers— I took to him my Public Letter-Book, with the press Copies, to be copied into it.

25. IV:30. This day was devoted altogether to my preparations for departure— I had three trunks packed up to be left with Mr Meulemeester; one of them, containing books, maps and other effects belonging to the joint mission, and the other two with effects of my own— I had a Card fixed upon each of the trunks having on it my name and character as Minister of the United States in Russia, and on the mission Trunk, a second Card, with a direction to R. G. Beasley, London— That trunk was numbered 1. and the others 2. and 3. I fixed similar Cards, with corresponding numbers to the keys of the several trunks, and wrote a Note, to be delivered to Mr Meulemeester, with the request that he would keep the trunks and keys, subject to further directions from me. Recollecting my wife’s request for table linen, I went to Corbisier’s, and purchased several pieces which I had packed up with the other effects. I had promised to sit an hour for Mr Van Huffel, but the time slipped away, until four O’Clock in the afternoon came, and I had scarcely time to call and take leave of him— I dined with Mr and Mrs Smith—immediately after dinner I called at Mr Meulemeester’s to take leave of him and his Lady, but they were both gone to the Theatre. I went there and took leave of the Ladies— The other Mrs Meulemeester, his Sister was also there— The performances were Ma Tante Aurore, and Joconde, the new comic Opera, for the first time. After the play, I called again at Mrs. Smith’s, and took leave of her, and of her neighbours Madame Marouques and her daughter. I intended to have paid visits in person to take leave of the Intendant and the Mayor, but the time failed— Mr Bauwens came, and brought me some calculations respecting the cost of making linen with machinery. I promised to answer his letter, from Bruxelles, or from Paris.

26. VI: Bruxelles. I had ordered my horses at ten O’Clock this Morning— Having yet partly to pack my trunks.— Antoine came to my chamber, just after I had kindled my fire, and we were both busied until eleven in finishing the preparations— I had
intended to call yesterday upon Mr Nuytens to take leave, but had not found a moment for the purpose. It was therefore necessary to write him a note, which I sent by the messenger of the Hotel— Nuytens the Son immediately came to my chamber at the Hotel, and took leave of me there— Mr Cornelissen did the same, and also Mr Meulemeester, who brought me the Music of the Couplets sung by his daughter on the 4th: instt:—they were written by Mr Cornelissen— I gave Mr Meulemeester the keys of the three trunks I leave with him, and my Letter to him of directions how to dispose of them— Mr Smith likewise came and took leave, and I requested him to see that the trunks should be sent to Mr Meulemeester’s in the course of the day. The largest of the three was already sent— At a quarter past eleven O’Clock I entered my Carriage, and left the Hotel des Pays-Bas, and the City of Ghent, probably never to see them again. My residence in the City has been of seven Months and two days, and it has been the most memorable period of my life. I left it with the Sentiments suitable to the occasion, of grateful regard for its Inhabitants, who have taken a strong interest in our success, and have shewn us many civilities and attentions; but above all with gratitude to Heaven for the signal favour to my Country in which I have participated at this place— There are three Stages between Ghent and Bruxelles—Quadrecht—Alost, and Assche— The distance is six and a quarter Posts— I left my Carriage only once at the first Stage; and landed at half past five in the afternoon at the Hotel de Flandre in Bruxelles— It was the coldest day there had been this winter, and was growing colder the whole day— The ground was covered with one sheet of snow the whole way; though not any where three inches deep— The travelling in sledges would have been excellent— After dining alone, I spent the Evening in my chamber, and attempted to write a little, without success— Between 9 and 10 I retired.

27. VI. The weather moderated in the course of the Night, and it snowed all the morning— I engaged myself so much in writing that it was too late to deliver my Letters before I could go out— At two O’Clock I took a walk about the City, and dined at three at the Table d’Hôte— There were eight persons at table; two of them Englishmen. One of them said that Reaumur’s Thermometer was last Evening at 17 degrees below 0. In my walk round the City I heard the English, French and Dutch spoken, about in equal proportions— There are three Regiments of English Guards here, and eight hundred English families settled here for the winter— I met a number of sledges, shaped in the form of Lions, Swans, and other Animals, with a Lady in each, and a Gentleman behind, driving her— It is a fashionable party of pleasure— The horses are harnessed with Bells— This Evening I went to the Theatre, and saw Caroline ou le Tableau, a Comedy in verse, and Raoul Barbe Bleue, with Grétry’s Music— I had seen Madame St James in the part of Isaure, at Ghent— The rest of the performers are much upon a level with those of Ghent— The Theatre is larger, but not so handsome— It has however the convenience of being heated by two Stoves, one in the parquet and one in the pit. The house was thin, and most of the Company appeared to be Strangers— I met there Captain Constant D’hane— They begin at six O’Clock and the Play was finished soon after nine.

28. VI. Finished a Letter which I had begun yesterday for my wife, and sent it to the Post-Office before Noon, the time when the Mail for Germany closes— Received a letter superscribed to me, and addressed to the Mission, from Messrs: Baring Brothers and Co: London, of the 17th: instt:— It was forwarded from Ghent, by Messrs: Meulemeester— I sent a copy of it, addressed to my Colleagues at Paris. Changed my Chamber at the Hotel from N. 17. up four pair of stairs, to N. 8 two Stories lower— The latter is a very good chamber, fronting upon the square— The other was a bad one— I delivered my Letters—two from the Meulemeester, to Mr Vlieshouwer, a lawyer, and to Mr Mosselman de Vette, a Merchant— The other was from the Willink’s, which they furnished me last June; to Mr L. Van der Velde— Mr Mosselman I was informed was at Antwerp and had been there these twelve days. He is expected back next week— Mr Vlieshouwer invited me to go and dine with him, at the Club of the literary Society;—which I did— On calling upon him at three O’Clock, I met at his apartments a Mr Vilain quatorze, a nephew of the Lady whose house we visited at Weteren on the second of October— The company at the dinner of the literary club were about thirty persons; well bred Gentlemen whom I found very sociable though I was not personally introduced to any of them— After dinner we passed into the reading room where I amused myself with the English Newspapers until 6 O’Clock— They were to the 20th:— I then returned home, and went to the Theatre where I saw Eugenie, and la Mélomanie— I went into the first and second row of boxes, and finally into the parquet. All the good boxes, as at Ghent are hired for the Season— I met Captain Constant D’hane there again— The play was tolerably well performed— The best actress is Madame Gouget— She performed the part of Eugenie, and last Evening that of Caroline. I recognized Desfosséz and Madame St: James in La Mélomanie.

29. VI. I took a warm Bath, this morning before breakfast— Mr Renwett came to me from Mr Vlieshouwer, mentioning that he had received last Evening, on returning home, an invitation from Mr Vilain quatorze, for himself and me to dine with him this day, at three O’Clock— I engaged to call upon him at that hour— At noon I attended the mass at the Church next door to the Hotel where I lodge— It was performed by a single Priest in so low a voice that I could not hear one word of it; and lasted about half an hour— They take deux liards, or a french sol, for every chair, to serve as a kneeling stool, and there are old women and boys going about the church, giving chairs and taking half-pence— And ordinance from the Chapter is posted up in the Church, authorizing the taking of these two liards for each Chair; and in the broad aisle, in the middle of the Church there was a box to receive money, and an incription in French and in Flemish Ici on offre, pour un nouveau throne, pour la Nôtre Dame de Bois le due. During the mass a man went about with a box to collect I suppose charity for the poor, shaking the half-pence in the box, to remind les fidéles, of their duty still further to replenish it— The Church was crowded with people, but there were many private conversations going on while the mass was performing— Whenever the kneeling time came an enfant de Choeur gave notice of it by the ringing of a Bell. This is their form of worship— A Mass every hour, from seven in the Morning until Noon; and the worshippers come in and go out when they please— After attending the Mass, I took a walk round the City, and went into the great Cathedral Church— The most remarkable objects in that are the painted windows, which are in very fine Colours, and well preserved. On the walls were posted Indulgences— A Mandement from the Archbishop of Mechlin, congratulating the people upon the deliverance of the Pope from captivity, and notice of a solemn mass to be performed on the first of February, the anniversary of the deliverance of Bruxelles— After returning home, I called at 3 O’Clock upon Mr Vlieshowwer and went with him to dine with Mr Vilain quatorze— I found here an elegant house; and Ladies, which was quite unexpected and for which I was not prepared— The company was not numerous; 11 persons at table; but an excellent dinner, and delicious wines— The Lady of the house, Madame Vilain quatorze is an elegant woman of french manners; the first thing she said to me was that she had a grossesse bien incommode— After dinner she invited me to play a game of billiards with her, and beat me with great ease— The company was mixed; among them one young English Officer— The tone of Conversation sprightly and agreeable, with a little affectation of courtliness, and frequent mention of the Prince, and his masquerade quadrille, to be given next monday week— At six O’Clock I came away, and went to the Theatre, where they performed La Servante Maitresse with the new Music of Paësiello, and La Caverne— Paësiello’s Music is always delightful, but I know not why he should encroach upon the property of his predecessor Pergolesi— I prefer the old Music of the Serva Padrona— The Music of La Caverne is too difficult for this Company, and tedious every where.

30. VI:15. I had visits this Morning, from Mr Lievin Bauwens of Ghent, and from a Mr Monnier van Manniert a native of this Country, but who has resided may years at Philadelphia, and there married a Miss Milner— He is now a widower, and has two daughters, both married— He was desirous of writing to America, and has the intention of going there himself the next Summer— About one O’Clock, Mr Renwett called upon me and went with me to see the Collection of Pictures of Mr Burtin— On the way he pointed out to me the house or rather the ruins where had been the house of Count Egmont.— I then recollected having seen the house when I was at Bruxelles before— It has since been demolished— We also went round by the marble fountain erected by the Testament of Bruce, Earl of Ailsbury an English Nobleman who resided forty years in this City, and left to his heir the order to erect this Monument as a token of his gratitude to the inhabitants of the place. He died in 1740. and the work was executed by Bergé, a sculptor of this Country in 1751— It is a costly monument, but gives no explanation how it happened that a British Peer, public-spirited enough to appropriate a part of his fortune to the comfort and embellishment of a foreign City, should have had so little of the Sentiment of patriotism, as to have lived as a private individual forty years absent from his Country and yet so near it— We were two hours in surveying Mr Burtin’s Collection, which is the choicest private Collection that I ever saw. He is himself a thorough Connoisseur in Painting, and a very proper object for a Painter. He is 72 years of age, and began by asking me, if I was an Amateur de Tableaux— I told him that I took great pleasure in looking at good Pictures; but that I could not assume the pretension of being an Amateur. He said he could give me in five minutes the secret which he had been forty years in learning, and which he had fully disclosed
in two Octavo Volumes that he had published, and which he hoped would by my means become known in America. Since the English had got in here, they had taken more than seventy copies of it, so that he had scarcely any left— The French considered his work as the first upon the subject, though he had treated the French school harshly, and Mr: Malte-Brun the critic had styled him a connoisseur trés eclairé, juge sevère mais impartial de l’ecole Françoise. His secret was to look at every picture as if the original was behind you, and you saw it in a mirror— If it appeared natural to you as an object reflected by a mirror, you might boldly pronounce it a good picture— If not you might as certainly pronounce it a bad one— As to the French School it could boast of only one good Painter, which was Eustache le Sueur— I asked him how he considered Poussin?— As an Italian Painter; formed altogether in Italy— How of Claud?— Why his very name said he was of Lorraine— And all his Art of Painting he learnt at Rome— But Rubens, said I studied likewise in Italy— Yes; but he was a great Painter before he went there— You will find it all explained at large in my Book— You see, said he this whole side of my library— It consists altogether of Books upon the Art of Painting—and excepting these four middle shelves, which are Catalogues of sales, with their prices, all the rest now that my book is published may be thrown into the fire— There is nothing further to be got from them. After this introduction we went and looked at the Pictures, and as the chambers were cold, Mr Burtin left us with his housekeeper, a pretty girl, who he said could explain to us the subjects of the Pictures as well as himself. They are in four small chambers, and all excellent pictures— He prides himself upon not having one indifferent Painting in the whole Collection— Besides the Standards of the Dutch and Flemish Schools, Mieris, Rembrandt, Teniers, Ostade, Jan Steen, Van Dyke and Rubens, There are four capital Portraits by Holbein, three pictures of Albert Durer, one of Michael Angelo, and a small Portrait of Titian painted by himself— The large Pictures appeared to me the least remarkable— The Water-pieces, flowers, dead game, living animals, and inside views of churches were like those in all good collections of the flemish school. A number of sketches, mere daubings of Rubens, and one admirable Portrait by the same Master— Several Landscapes like most others; and a singular portrait of Terburg, painted by himself, a bitter Satire upon his disciple Caspar Netscher and upon William 3d. the Prince of Orange— After having admired these nearly two hours Mr Burtin sent his maid with us to see his four finest pictures in a separate chamber— They were covered with green silk veils— A Marriage of St. Catherine, the Master-Piece of Van Dyke— A St: Francis by Rubens; a Christ bearing his Cross by Leonardo da Vinci; and last and most exquisitely beautiful of all, a holy family by Guido— If it was mine I would not give it for all the rest of the Collection. The most perfect ideal head of the Virgin, that was perhaps ever painted. I took a copy of Mr Burtin’s Book and returned home— Dined at the Table d’Hote and spent the afternoon and Evening in my chamber, alone; reading and writing.

31. VI:15. Employed the Morning in writing to my wife, and left the Letter to be finished to-morrow Morning.— Wrote also one or two other Letters. I had intended to go and hear the proceedings at the tribunal of appeal, and Mr Renwet, who is an Avoue, or lawyer of that Court had described to me the place where it is held so that I thought I could have found it alone. But on making the attempt I failed— After walking round the Park, and on the Ramparts of the City, I went to the Old Palace to see the Museum, the Cabinet of Natural History and the Public Library— But the Concierge was not to be found— After another walk round the City, I returned to the Hotel de Flandre— Dined at the Table d’Hote, and went in the Evening to the Theatre, where I saw Moliere’s Etourdi, ou les Contretems, and Le Calife de Bagdad— They perform their Comedies here, much better than their Opera’s— I had never seen l’Etourdi performed upon the Stage— Their performance of the Caliph of Bagdad was worse than at Ghent— I received this Morning, a Card from Madame Van de Velde, the mother I presume of the young man to whom I delivered the Letter from Messrs. Willink of Amsterdam— It was an invitation to dinner on Friday— I hesitated a moment whether to decline or to postpone my departure from Bruxelles; but I concluded to persist in going as I had determined; that is, on Thursday, & wrote a note of excuse to Madame Van de Velde— Mr Bauwens called again to see me; and I gave him the answer to his Letter— He promised to call upon me to-morrow morning, and to accompany me to the Tribunal of appeal.

Day. The first remark upon the present Month is a relaxation with regard to my hour of rising— It has more than once been by day-light; and one as late as seven O’Clock— The Mission Meetings have ceased— While I remained at Ghent my chief occupation was copying and arranging Papers— I dined at half-past One O’Clock instead of five and had a long afternoon and short Morning— At Bruxelles I have dined at three— In other respects my habitual day continues as heretofore.
